title: Zone 2 Training
content: Zone 2 training is defined as your highest metabolic output/work that you can sustain while keeping your lactate level below two millimole per liter (mmol/L). It is a measure of how metabolically healthy you are and how good your mitochondria are. The fitter a person is, the healthier a person is, the more work they can do with less lactate. For a given individual, we use this metric of zone 2 as a place to understand how metabolically healthy they are, how good their mitochondria are, and how much work can be done while keeping your lactate about 1.7 to 2.0 mmol/L.

title: Engaging in Zone 2 Exercise
content: The most effective ways to engage in zone 2 exercise include using a bicycle, treadmill, rowing machine, or elliptical. When doing zone 2, you want a machine where it's very easy to reproducibly produce the same output. For most people, running gets them out of zone two a little too quickly. With patients, brisk walking on an incline is preferred. You have to figure out which incline and speed will keep you, personally, in zone 2, but once you know then you can set it and go.

title: Training a Deconditioned Individual with Zone 2
content: Training a deconditioned or metabolically ill individual can be a challenge. Someone who is very metabolically ill may be already at 2 mmol of lactate at rest. So right after they jump on the bike their lactate starts to shoot up. Essentially, they are immediately getting out of mitochondrial oxidation and they’re burning nearly all glucose instead of fat. In the beginning, rely on what’s called rate of perceived exertion (RPE). Combing that metric with heart rate and lactate and you can start to triangulate on zone 2.

title: Exercise Recommendations
content: Ideally, individuals should exercise up to three hours a week, with no sessions shorter than about 45 minutes. The minimum effective dose is really three hours a week. It is recommended to do three or four sessions weekly no shorter than 45 minutes per session. In an ideal world, one would do four two-hour sessions per week. It is better to do three one hour sessions than six 30 minute sessions. Each session should be at least 45 minutes.

title: Training for Health vs. Performance
content: Even elite athletes spend about 70% of their time in zone 2, but they typically do workouts that vary in intensity through the session depending on what sport they are training for. Non-athletes should not be trying to mix and match zones. A typical regimen might include a session of zone 2 only, a session of zone 5 only, and a HIIT session separately.

title: Fasted State Training
content: Training in a fasted state is recommended for maximum substrate—meaning as much fatty acid and glucose available for muscles. The way to maximize fatty acid availability is to have insulin level be as low as possible, because insulin impairs lipolysis. It has been observed that the higher the glucose level during a zone 2, the higher the lactate level will be.

title: Improving Mitochondrial Density and Function
content: A benefit of zone 2 training is increasing mitochondrial density & function. It is hard to know without more extensive studies with biopsies whether it increases in all muscles during zone 2 training or is it just the primary muscles being worked.

title: Monitoring Fitness Levels
content: Zone 2 exercise done properly should improve mitochondrial function, fat utilization, and lactate clearance. With zone 2 done properly, you should see improving fat oxidation, improving lactate clearance, and therefore improved mitochondrial function. And with those improvements, you should technically be able to increase your output while staying in your zone 2.

title: Choosing Exercise Equipment
content: For most people, it’s much easier to maintain zone 2 via walking on a treadmill at an incline or getting on a decent bicycle. Most people are not able to get to zone 2 with walking on a flat ground. In most cases, people are actually escaping zone 2 when running (i.e., intensity too high).

title: Back Pain and Exercise
content: Being more active and mobile can help in terms of decreasing in the back pain. It may seem counterintuitive to some, but exercise in its different forms, resistance training, aerobic training, stability can help with back pain.

title: Magnesium Supplementation
content: Magnesium is a super important mineral found at its highest quantity in bone (about 50-60% present in bones and most of the rest in soft tissues). Magnesium depletion is not uncommon even for otherwise healthy people. The good thing about magnesium is it a low risk supplement (with normal kidneys). It’s a big part of maintaining the potassium concentration in the cell—An action potential requires sodium to rush in a cell and potassium to rush out of a cell. And those gradients have to be maintained. That requires electromagnetic force. Magnesium plays an important role in that.

title: Magnesium Intake During Fasting
content: When people are fasting, they struggle to get enough sodium, potassium, and especially magnesium. Patients complaining of cramping with or without a fast may not be getting enough magnesium. A protocol suggests taking 2 tablets of Slow Mag when not fasting; When fasting, 3-4 tablets. Magnesium L-threonate is less about the magnesium and more about what L-threonate does. L-threonate is a CNS transporter—magnesium doesn’t cross the blood brain barrier very effectively so the threonate is taking whatever magnesium you’ve got and getting it into the CNS. It’s being investigated for its potential benefits in the treatment of mild cognitive impairment and may improve sleep.

title: Magnesium Protocol
content: A magnesium protocol involves taking 3 forms of magnesium: oxide, chloride (Slow Mag), and L-threonate (Magtein). When NOT fasting, take ~400-500 mg of oxide (morning), 2 tablets of Slow Mag (morning), and 2 capsules of Magtein (before bed). When fasting, stop the oxide, take a double dose of Slow Mag, and continue to take Magtein before bed.

title: Engaging with Your Doctor
content: Physicians are often in a tough position with many needing to see upwards of 6 patients an hour to maintain their practice. This limits the time they have for answering questions from patients unrelated to the particular visit. It's recommended to send them an email before your appointment to give them a chance to reflect on your questions. If the doctor is dismissive of what you want to discuss, then you have a right to find another doctor. Medicine comes down to these four A’s: advocacy, affability, availability, and ability. If you’re not getting an answer that you’re comfortable with from your doctor, you should find another doctor.
